/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Could the following logs also be a symptom of this issue?

After controller-1 is reinstalled with N+1 load on an upgrade and first host-unlock; I notice the following in the controller-1 puppet.log (attached):
2020-03-26T19:32:28.565 /usr/share/openvswitch/scripts/dpdk-devbind.py --bind=vfio-pci 0000:06:13.7
..
2020-03-26T19:32:30.181 Notice: 2020-03-26 19:32:30 +0000 /Stage[main]/Platform::Interfaces::Sriov/Platform::Interfaces::Sriov_config[sriovfio]/Exec[sriov-vf-bind-device: sriovfio]/returns: Unknown device: 0000:06:11.5. Please specify device in "bus:slot.func"

However, if I were then to run /usr/share/openvswitch/scripts/dpdk-devbind.py --bind=vfio-pci 0000:06:11.5, it now appears to pass.
i.e.  controller-1: /usr/share/openvswitch/scripts/dpdk-devbind.py --bind=vfio-pci 0000:06:11.5
         0000:06:11.5 already bound to driver vfio-pci, skipping
Thanks Steve for the confirmation and fix.

Hi John, I was seeing something similar while developing this fix.  The driver bind was happening before the VFs were applied by the interface pre-up.  In the corresponding stx-puppet fix at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/715669/ I've put a dependency on the bind run after the network apply step.  That seems to resolve things.

We currently prevent the setting of the number of VFs to 0 via semantic check, but I do see what you are saying.  The check is here to prevent a VF sub-interface from setting the number of VFs on the PF.  Perhaps it's better to use a value of 'None' for this case in-case we do want to support a case of clearing the number of VFs.
Should really be using "Anchor['platform::networking']" to execute this after networking has been applied
FYI: in the future this should have targeted a ::params class that took the shared configuration for both the config and runtime classes.  So you would not have needed the runtime flag.
This will still work, but why did you need to move this out of the require?
I've just tested this and indeed it could have been in the require as well

specs/approved/manual-deploying.rst.message: Shouldn't this be 'user' (rather than operators) as later on you use 'nova resize' as the trigger for such configuration changes? From what I understand, the whole spec is about giving user means to reconfigure their instances.
Yes, you're right. Updated in the latest patch.

Nit: Sounds very specific. I suggest:
* Change of BIOS settings, e.g. to disable hyper-threading ...
we can also control CPU prefetching behavior through BIOS settings.
Done
Added in the examples list. Thanks!
s/operators/users/
Done
ditto
Done
Nit: applies
Done
Users?
Done

From what I understand, resize() would basically be the user side trigger to reconfigure a physical instance. And you chose this since the configuration change to apply is the delta between two flavors (as I had initially thought that rebuild() would sound more intuitive) ... is that correct?

Another question:
If nova resize() is passed a new flavor that differs only in traits and can be served from the same node, will nova (or placement) actually realize? I think what we'd like to avoid is re-doing the scheduling followed by a cold-migration, no?

A rebuild recreates the instance on the same node, overwriting all disk. Whereas a reconfigure will only apply few settings on an active node, no recreation or disk deletion is done here.

For the second question, the resize will do no rescheduling. The initial target of implementation of resize for Ironic driver in Nova is to:
* apply the traits on the same node.
* if traits don't match, the resize fails.
What happens when the traits cannot be fulfilled by the same node?
The resize will fail.
I don't understand how the conductor does this ... has it booted the node into the deploy image, is there something listening on the instance, ...? Could you elaborate this a bit?
Ok I have added more detail in the latest patch. Thanks!
s/operators/users/
Done
RECONFIGURING
Done
Should this be 'RECONFIGURING'?
Done
see above
Done
see above
Done
RECONFIGURE?
Done
I'd call this the ironic driver in nova. Maybe add a reference, so we are sure?
Done
apply? or "perform certain configuration changes"
Done
Most of the OOB deploy steps need reboot to make check if the step is completed successfully. This requires rebooting of the server. Do we need to add RECONFIGUREWAIT state to handle that?
Yes, you're right. I will add that. Thanks!

Do we need this 'RECONFIGURE' state as node would internally move to 'ACTIVE' immediately after that. Can't it be made to move to 'ACTIVE' upon completing all the steps from 'RECONFIGURING' state itself?
Yes, it is indeed desirable.
shouldn't this be RECONFIGURE ?  (from complete to succeeds)
Yes. I will change this.
I'm not sure if this is possible. We do not allow 'delete' while node is in 'DEPLOYING' state.
Ok I will remove this.
Shouldn't this be a deploy template?

Ideally, Yes! because a deploy_step might not be supported by the hardware.

So if we provide the deploy_template, ironic can check if the requested deploy_template is supported by the baremetal node or not.
This name is a bit misleading. I think we're talking about reconfiguration here. To me, manual deployment means specifying a list of deploy steps when provisioning a node.
Done.
This will confuse Nova, unless we hide this new state in older microversions.

In the older version of the software, reconfigure support will not exist. So how is this issue possible?
Sorry I am not able to understand the issue here.
Can you explain an example case? Thanks!

I'm not sure. At the very least we'll have to update nova to understand the new states when tracking nodes. But we also need something for older software to not break. Maybe we need to hide the new state completely, pretending the nodes are active? I'm not sure.
The new state will need a new microversion. How can this be solved then?
Only one?
Sorry, this should be deploy_steps.
If we're doing this using deploy templates rather than deploy steps, it's not really analogous to manual cleaning.
Done
We likely need a way to mark steps as compatible with reconfiguration. E.g. RAID is not compatible.
apply_configuration and delete_configuration are the RAID supported deploy steps.
Is there a specific raid related deploy_step that should be not allowed?
RAID could be compatible if you don't reconfigure the root disk.
Yes, good point. I will introduce a new param in the next patchset. Thanks!
This workflow is a little different from the one for deployment. For deployment, we pass the traits via node.instance_info.traits, and ironic matches these against deploy templates.
On a practical level, it is much easier for us to get code merged in ironic than nova. Using the existing approach keeps the nova changes small.
Nova still has to deal with traits. We pass the new trait in flavor, Ironic virt driver filters it and choose the corresponding deploy-step to run. Does that make sense?

It makes sense. We could have designed the deploy templates feature to work that way, but we didn't. Now we're proposing to use a different model for reconfigure, and I don't see why. It should be possible to make it work with the existing traits based model of interaction.

Isn't the current approach the same? Does ironic virt driver look for matching deploy_template? Or is it Ironic which looks for the matching deploy_templates corresponding to the instance_info.traits?

It just seems a little odd to me that it works differently from deployment. Currently nova is not aware of deploy steps or deploy templates. It just passes traits to ironic. If we make nova aware of this, we will need to push a lot of code into nova, which we already have in ironic.

No, the virt driver only sets instance_info.traits on the node. It doesn't know about deploy templates.

Everything else is done by ironic, mostly in here: https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/branch/master/ironic/conductor/steps.py

Yes, you're right. Because we need to send deploy_steps as a parameter to the reconfigure API.
I am trying to make this API independent so that it can be used outside Nova as well.
RECONFIGUREWAIT
Done
We need some sort of backward compatibility, otherwise Nova and others won't recognize the new states as equivalent of ``active``.

Given that deploy templates are sort of a subset of trains in ironic, what will happen with node.instance_info[traits] after reconfiguration?

Similarly, we should probably enforce that the requested deploy template is in the node's traits list.

The node.instance_info[traits] will be updated to include the new trait after reconfiguration.
Rescheduling to the same host without a claim will be done to ensure that the existing node supports the requested trait.
As I noted above, we need to research what happens with older nova and newer ironic.
I am thinking about how the incompatibilities in older versions were handled?

specs/approved/node-reconfigure.rst.message:
While changing the BIOS settings is certainly a valid use case (I think it was even me adding this as a potential application early on, sorry ;-), it would require quite some flavors to cover the numerous BIOS options (since FWIU the user cannot pass any additional options ... or is that possible?) ... In addition, there are different BIOS implementations (item organization and naming), and no common interface to set/unset these remotely (via IPMI, for instance). If we make this a prominent use case (which I am sure operators can relate to), how about we add something to explain what a "hyperthreading on/off" reconfigure step would actually entail?
But maybe that's beyond the general idea of adding such a framework ...?

We can pass different options to the deploy template we create in Ironic. For example, in case of Intel SST-PP, users need to send the configuration hexadecimal code (0x00, 0x01 or 0x00).

Each of the deploy steps meant for reconfiguration should implement the interface/method to apply the changes to the node and reboot if required. For instance, the Intel SST-PP needs to send an ipmi call and a reboot is required to reflect the change. So the corresponding deploy step should implement these steps as a whole.

Now about adding details of the deploy steps, we can update the "node-deployment" doc to include details about each of them, same as we do for clean steps https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/admin/cleaning.html

specs/newton/metadata-add-ipv6-support.r.message: It doesn't seem a conclusion was ever reached in this bug, but using a DNS SRV record seemed like more of an option than anycast.

Alexey - I'm actually fine using a link-local address for this, but I'd rather have it discoverable since that gives us flexibility in deployments.  Perhaps in a provider network it can be a global within the datacenter?

DNS and RA require additional configuration, which is not always possible.  For Metadata service, VM only needs to access DHCP agent or L3 router, and it located in the same L2 segment by design.  This is why IPv6 Link Local address is a simplest solution.
Because I fell this is an abuse of the "anycast is indistinguishable from unicast", since it's a link-local address.  DNS gets around that, or an RA option.

Let's not forget that is must work in all cases, not only provider networks, but also in user-created private networks without router (or with disconnected router). Anyway, there are several choices for such discovery:

Global DNS name, like "instance-data.".  Requires DNS configuration, doesn't work if instances uses external DNS servers.

Zeroconf/mDNS discovery.  Easy to use, may have security issues(?), esp. in shared networks, requires additional service running on DHCP/L3 agent.

"Well-known" IPv6 Multicast address, that is used to discover metadata service (just like DHCPv6 server discovery). A bit more complex for clients, but "well-known" address is not cached on client - re-discovery will select next available server. This "well-known" address also need to be IANA-registered.

Link-Local IPv6 anycast address described here (no discovery). Uses Linux-specific anycast API on server side, have problems with NDP cache, easy to use for clients, can work in any environment.

Use IPv4 Metadata URL and allow communication on 169.254.0.0/16 network.  Clients will use IPv4LL autoconfiguration.  Additional firewall rules may be specified to only allow client-to-metadata communication.

Every method have it's own advantages and disadvantages...
Why you think so?  Anycast address works with only Neutron support, while DNS SRV needs additional configuration, which is not always possible.
it's not magic. It's just an arbitrary link local v4 address that amazon picked. Let's be clear.
I would suggest "well known" instead of "magic".

That really isn't an anycast address (even if RFC 4291 is unclear on it) as a router should be able to forward packets to one of a group of systems with it.  Link-local addresses are not forwarded.  And you'd need an assignment from IANA (RFC 2526).  And you're using the word "group" which is a multicast concept, so I'm confused.

This is an address that can be IPV6_JOIN_ANYCAST'ed (option 27 for setsockopt(2)). RFC 4291 says, that "anycast addresses are syntactically indistinguishable from unicast addresses". It also doesn't says, that this address MUST be Reserved IPv6 Anycast (RFC 2526).
Ah, the reverse mapping is done automatically by the kernel. Well, we need an address in the global unicast scope to be the well known metadata IPv6 metadata address.

Brian, you are right, there is a window for metadata availability in IPv6 anycast "failover" scenario. For IPv4 it is much worse, because we have metadata IPv4LL assigned on the interface, so clients will get ARP replies from inactive agents as well, e.g. no failover at all.

There is still a window where a client could do NDP, get a response, but the anycast is removed right after.  The resulting http get would fail until the cached entry goes stale, even if another host has the anycast.  Perhaps we have the same problem with IPv4 but have never seen it.

If an anycast address is registered in the kernel, neighbour discovery logic changes to keep single neighbour by always sending neighbour advertisments with non-override flag. On reprobe the client will get multiple replies and will pick the one which does not override the current address. In case metadata-proxy process exits for any reason the kernel will unregister and stop responding to NDP on IPv6 anycast address, so the client will choose different agent for metadata. That's how anycast supposed to work on local subnet.

IPv6 link local as a metadata address provides the same advantages as IPv4 link local (169.254.169.254) we use now, plus better support on clients (link local is not optional in IPv6 as it in IPv4).

But the whole point of anycast is for the last-hop router to only forward it to *one* of many systems, and that can't happen in this case.

And regarding Reserved - it seems we are trying to standardize something, how do we do that without agreeing to what this address should be?  Baking it into neutron isn't the place to standardize it.  This was mentioned in the bug as well.

fe80::169.254.169.254 is in the link-local prefix, as such any packets sent to it will be sent from other link-local addresses rather than global unicast addresses. Redirecting link-local traffic is in effect routing it, which is prohibited. Could we use the IPv6 mapped IPv4 address for metadata instead (::ffff:168.254.169.254) instead since it is in the global unicast scope?

Additionally I'm unclear how this anycast would be implemented: IPv6 provides multicast, but using multicast with TCP is problematic since the client will receive a reply from each member of the group.

Link Local address is better because this network is not routed.  In networks with external router, this router will receive packets directed to this "global unicast" address.  Then it should redirect it to Metadata proxy, but altering external router configuration is not always possible.

Instead of messing with "well-known" addresses, it is possible to use DHCP agent's Link Local address, but client needs a way to discover it.  cloud-init for CloudStack datasource parses *.lease files from DHCP client and uses DHCP server's address as metadata URI.  This will not work for IPv6-only SLAAC networks.  Using address of default router will not work for networks with external router...

> Could we use the IPv6 mapped IPv4 address for metadata 
> instead (::ffff:168.254.169.254) instead since it is in the 
> global unicast scope?

That would just be transmitted as an IPv4 address, so don't know if it would work without the presence of an IPv4 source address on the system.  A system shouldn't ever send this address on the wire as-is.
Please, no IPv4 embedded addresses. Just no.
fe80::169.254.169.254 isn't a valid IPv6 address, are you thinking of a 6to4 address?

Sean M. Collins, It's not actually embedding. It's mnemonic. Do you have any objections about fe80::a9fe:a9fe?

Brian Haley, it couldn't be autoassigned in any way (see Dmitry Bilunov comment). Futhermore, attribution to "infrastructure" ports could be enforced with SG framework (like it was done for e.g. DHCPv4).

Ok, valid, but not the correct way:

http://v6decode.com/#address=fe80%3A%3A169.254.169.254

I've never seen a link-local address using dotted notation.

Right, but embedding the v4 address is typically only done as some transition mechanism, and for viewing purposes (like in netstat).  This address, starting with fe80, would always be displayed as fe80::a9fe:a9fe in any utility because they don't know it has any "special" meaning.

The reason I keep harping on this is that without some reservation of the address it has no special meaning as a metadata address, and that's what we're trying to do here.  Because we then have to make sure anti-spoofing rules are in place so it can't be configured on a VM, etc.
fe80::a9fe:a9fe is a good choice since it cannot be auto-assigned to the interface since it lacks "ff:fe" part (as in Modified EUI-64) in the middle of interface identifier.
@Brian: I think it's fine here, embedding an IPv4 address in an IPv6 address allowed, and this shows the intent for it to be an equivalent address.
That's another way to represent fe80::a9fe:a9fe address.

Alexey - maybe I was just reading fe80::169.254.169.254 too literally, and not seeing it as just why a9fe:a9fe was chosen, my apologies.

But it is possible for a VM to assign this address, one simple way is to create a port with the right MAC manually, then use it at boot time.  So if we go forward with this, we'll need to make sure that address is only ever allowed on "infrastructure" ports used for handling it.

As far as I can see, embedding 169.254.169.254 to IPv6 link-local in IPv4-mapped IPv6 addresses manner is just "number play" to keep well-known number.

So any address may be chosen, but personally I like this one fe80::a9fe:a9fe. At least it as easy to say/remember/type it, as 169.254.169.254 was.

And speaking about reservation, 169.254.169.254 is reserved de facto, not de jure. We shoud play same way.

fe80::169.254.169.254 is just an explanation why fe80::a9fe:a9fe address was chosen.

With current anti-spoofing rules VM can't assign this address. DHCP agent will accept connection (because port security is off for network-owned ports) and client will receive reply if connection was established.
How is it okay to be listening on all interfaces in the L3 router case? With if the router gateway interface is connected to a provider network shared with another OpenStack installation?

To join any anycast going, an interface needs to be specified. This should be changed to: Metadata proxy joins anycast group fe80::a9fe:a9fe on each internal interface (i.e. not qg- interfaces in qrouter- namespaces).

Additionally, the Python socket module don't define constants for IPV6_JOIN_ANYCAST, but we could define this constant locally.

I see a small problem with this proposal. VM, at least a normal non-tweaked operating system IPv6 stack, will require IPv6 neighbor resolution for the address fe80::a9fe:a9fe, since this is pure L2 address and it is interface dependent. Otherwise IMHO just won't work. And no IP neighbor spoofing mechanism is mentioned here, although is needed.
According to everything I can read here in this proposal, I believe you're trying to recreate the behavior from IPv4 where you can do NAT in between, for that non link-local addresses must be used... Potential candidate for that might be ULA, maybe something like fd00:a9fe:a9fe::1/64 which can be NAT-ed in between. And just for the record, doing NAT in IPv6 sounds really awful, but may serve the purpose.

If I'm getting this right, each interface for each VM on a compute host will reply with its own MAC address, so the packet flow will be:
from VM: ICMP6, neighbor solicitation, who has fe80::a9fe:a9fe
to the VM (from the specific interface with MAC address of that particular interface on the same L2/bridge as VM): ICMP6, neighbor advertisement, tgt is fe80::a9fe:a9fe

Is there any chance that somebody has at least partial prototype of this working and tested? And if yes, are there any examples how packet/connection flow looks like?

Metadata proxy joins anycast group on this address, there's no need for spoofing nor NAT.
Can't use multicast address here because one does not simply open TCP connection to multicast address.  It may be used to resolve link-local address of one of the metadata services (if there's more than one DHCP agents available), but this process is more complex than just connecting to link-local anycast IP.

Yes, we have working installation, and yes, you are correct about packet flow.  tcpdump is too wide to quote it here, I've posted in on github - https://gist.github.com/raorn/6af30b6d6289640a548612400ee3b758

specs/ussuri/metadata-add-ipv6-support.r.message:
s/a DHCP or L3 agent.

At least I think that gets the point across
We should explain why we chose this address - it is the IPv6 link-local equivalent of fe80:"169.254.269.254" - there's probably a more RFC-like way to say that.
please explain why this address is safe to use.

I'm not sure we can make the assumption that DNS is available and/or usable for this purpose in all deployments.  If it's possible to go with a reserved address that solves a number of issues.  For example, if an operator was hypothetically concerned about DNS spoofing then using the IP would be a must; I have worked in environments where that was the case.

Sure, we can ask about it but I'm now looking at https://www.iana.org/assignments/iana-ipv6-special-registry/iana-ipv6-special-registry.xhtml and comparing it to https://www.iana.org/assignments/iana-ipv4-special-registry/iana-ipv4-special-registry.xhtml and on this ipv4 special registy page there is only 169.254/16 mentioned as link-local class. It's the same for ipv6 already.
So I don't think we will need anything else here.
Yamamoto - yes, it gets back to a comment I made years ago when we were looking at this.  We would need to go to the IETF and request it be reserved for this purpose

@Brian: do we really need to ask them for reservation of this IP?
According to https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3927 169.254/16 is IPv4 link-local subnet. Proposed here fe80::a9fe:a9fe is it's equivalent in IPv6 link-local subnet (FE80::/10 according to https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4291) so I think we should be fine to use it for that purpose, no?
How about using address like:  0:0:0:0:0:ffff:a9fe:a9fe  according to https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4291#section-2.5.5 ? Or did I misunderstood something there?

Slawek - I don't know if it's required, but it's good practice, https://www.iana.org/assignments/iana-ipv6-special-registry/iana-ipv6-special-registry.xhtml

I guess for IPv4 we just use something in the 169.254.0.0./16 space, which is registered as reserved, so maybe I'm over-thinking it.

We could just as easily add 'metadata' (or metadata.$domain) in DNS and have the instance resolve it, which we've talked about in other discussions. We have to move forward with something though...

s/The VM

We should mention this address needs to be configured in cloud-init in (new) images that get created.
I don't understand what "source interface" means.  It seems to be implying it's from the perspective of the instance?

(copying Dmitry Bilunov' comment in the cover comment to make it easier to track the discussion)

if you enable IPv6 on an interface, it would get two IPv6 addresses; one for link-local connectivity (auto-generated from MAC using EUI-64) and another router address for everything else (which is usually referred as "VM IP"). That another address is usually configured using either autoconf (by kernel processing the RA from the router), or by DHCPv6 client. If you attempt to make a connection to a link-local address (such as the proposed address of the metadata service, fe80::a9fe:a9fe%eth0), it would originate from the link-local address of the interface. So the metadata service would get a packet with VM's MAC in L2 and EUI-64'ed VM's MAC in L3, never seeing a normal "VM IP" in L3.

Why do we need to use an L2 address of a VM? Could you explain more detail on why the proposed logic is needed?

As of now, in case of IPv4, the metadata agent resolves an instance ID and its tenant ID based on (remote address of VM, network ID, router ID). I would like to know how the current logic does not work in case of IPv6.

So we would use the gateway MAC from the dhcp or router namespace?  Why can't we use the VM link-local IPv6 address?

Also, any changes to what we send to the Nova metadata  service has implications for that as well, so we would need to work with them on this, to make sure we pass enough information to identify the correct instance.
As long as we will be able to determine vm id (device_id in port's attributes) and we can send it to nova, I don't think any changes on nova's side would be required.

Before starting to work with the implementation, I wanted to test a metadata-like request manually in my devstack. Here's an etherpad showing that test in a dhcp namespace:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/metadata-ipv6-model

The test worked. Please comment here or there, if you'd do anything differently.

I also want to reproduce the same in a router namespace, but I don't have that yet.
I think I get what we mean by 'anycast group' here, but since a link-local address is never really routed, I'm not sure if this is technically anycast.
Why do we need to redirect anything (I guess redirect means a DNAT rule)? In the etherpad linked above I needed nothing like that.

For DHCP agent it is indeed simply configured on tapXXX interface but in case of L3 agent this metadata IP is configured as REDIRECT in iptables:

-A neutron-l3-agent-PREROUTING -d 169.254.169.254/32 -i qr-+ -p tcp -m tcp --dport 80 -j REDIRECT --to-ports 9697

I updated this part.

How would one specify generic interface name in metadata_urls for fe80:: address? Address http://fe80::a9fe:a9fe/ needs to look like: http://fe80::a9fe:a9fe%interface_name/. And interface name might not be always eth0.
http://[fe80::a9fe:a9fe%25eth0]/ see rfc6874 for more details

I don't see a problem in iterating through available interfaces on the system and using link-local address, which can be done in cloud-init code, but this wouldn't work for described workaround / interim period, if I understood the intention correctly.

In most cases it will be the first interface which is plugged to the VM, so this discovery shouldn't be hard IMO. But later we can maybe propose, as Bence suggested, new datasource for cloud-init and add some kind of discovery of the interface in it.

So that might indeed be an argument against using a link-local address, as it would force consumers like cloud-init to handle interface specifics instead of being able to just pull data from some generic source.

Syntactically yes, this is right. But this also means we'd have to predict guest-internal interface names when configuring cloud-init. That sounds impossible to do in a generic way.

I guess one way to overcome the need for prediction would be to pass an incomplete address like http://[fe80::a9fe:a9fe], let cloud-init detect this and do some guest-internal discovery which interface should be appended.
yes, exactly. I just updated it :)

I was trying to do the PoC for the router namespace and I may have found a problem with that.

For IPv4, 169.254.169.254 is not configured in the router namespace. Instead we push a route into the guest routing table for example:

169.254.169.254 via 10.0.0.1 dev ens2 proto dhcp metric 100

Despite 169.254 being link-local the kernel happily obeys this route and sends packets to 169.254.169.254 to the ethernet address of 10.0.0.1. That is nobody has to answer arp who-has 169.254.169.254 in the router namespace. (Later we catch this traffic via a REDIRECT to where haproxy listens but that does not matter here.)

It seems to me the linux kernel (here 4.15.0) behaves differently for ipv6. After the link-local configuration of the primary guest interface we already have routes like:

fe80::/64 dev ens2 proto kernel metric 256 pref medium
default via fe80::f816:3eff:fe90:2c07 dev ens2 proto ra metric 100 mtu 1450 pref medium

Then I add routes like (as if they were pushed by dhcp):

fe80::a9:fe:a9:fe via fe80::f816:3eff:fe90:2c07 dev ens2 metric 255 pref medium
fe80::a9:fe:a9:fe via fe80::f816:3eff:fe90:2c07 dev ens2 metric 257 pref medium

(Did not look up if 255 or 257 is stronger than 256 instead added both.)

The 'ip -6 route add' command succeeds, the entries can be seen in the routing table.

On the other hand the kernel seems to ignore them as it can be verified by tcpdump it still sends neighbor solicitation who-has fe80::a9:fe:a9:fe.

Which of course nobody answers in the router namespace. So the kernel gives up and does not send it to the router.

(This actually looks more logical than the ipv4 behavior since why would the kernel ever send link-local traffic to a router.)

We clearly cannot configure the same address in both the dhcp and the router namespaces because the second will fail at duplicate address detection.

I'm thinking what to do, just first wanted to share the problem I seem to have found.
The mismatch in the address is totally accidental. On the other hand I am going to re-check today if I used the same address consistently in my tests otherwise it may have caused a difference.

Sorry guys, my comment from yesterday was a false alarm. I did mix up the addresses and that's why I thought the kernel is ignoring the routes I installed. But actually it's not ignoring them.

As long as the route we install for fe80::a9fe:a9fe is more specific than the fe80::/64 entry present by default even the routing metric does not matter. So its presence is not a problem.

Thank you Tomislav for catching my silliness.

Added the PoC of the router namespace to the etherpad:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/metadata-ipv6-model
Thanks both for checking this possible issue.
Thx Bence and Tomislav for checking that. So it seems that this concept is still valid and we can go this way with implementation :)

The behavior looks correct. IPv6 does not use ARP, instead it uses Neighbor Discovery Protocol (by using ICMPv6). All link local IPv6 addresses must be bound to a specific interface if I understand implementation (and theory) correctly, and there should be no way to define it in routing table.

Address used in your example (fe80::a9:fe:a9:fe) is different compared to proposal from this document (fe80::a9fe:a9fe), not sure if that was accidental or intentional, although it would not have different outcome.

Hi hongbin, per we discuss in the meeting, I don't really prefer to use HEAT to realize the deployment tools, since the template is not friendly to end user. Is is possible to change another tools to implementation this?

Kevin,

Good suggestion. Agree with you that Heat's DSL might not be a user-friendly language. Right now, I couldn't find an existing alternative DSL to replace Heat. If there is an alternative DSL, I think it needs to satisfy the following:

* Is able to orchestration Zun containers with other OpenStack resources (i.e. Neutron load balancer, floating IP)
* Is a declarative language
* Better to be a well-known language that can serve as a standard and easy to pick up.

If you or anyone else could brainstorm an alternative that satisfies above requirements, please feel free to suggest. Perhaps we should investigate on the configuration management tools (i.e. Chef, Puppet) and their embedded DSL? Not sure.

I think we can do is to make this feature to be deployment tools agnostic. In particular, we could try to detect the type of the template file (check if it is a Heat template or something else) and invoke the corresponding tools based on the detected types?

Since more settings will make user dizzy

Agree with you, but it is up to the package developer to decide which settings will be made available to their users. We just provide tool for them to do it. What we can do later is to write a best-practice guide for package developers to explain the trade-off between options and complexity.

ansible/roles/cumulus-switch/README.md.message: micronit: Could we call this bridge1 or something to make the `post` command examples above a little clearer?

I double-checked in Cumulus, the NCLU interface mandates that a bridge is named bridge if it is VLAN-aware.

cumulus@cumulus:~$ net add bridge 
    <interface>  :  Name of a VLAN Unaware Bridge Interface
    lo           :  interface
    eth0         :  interface
    swp1         :  interface
    swp2         :  LLDP peer cumulus
    swp3         :  LLDP peer cumulus
    alias        :  description/alias
    bridge       :  Name of the VLAN Aware Bridge (must be bridge)

This is probably because you cannot have more than one VLAN-aware bridge on a given switch, though I agree that it makes the commands very confusing!

I will try to make a nicer example with a VLAN unaware bridge, or with another type of interface.

Every single documentation page I've seen from Cumulus names their bridge `bridge`. See for example https://docs.cumulusnetworks.com/display/DOCS/VLAN-aware+Bridge+Mode#VLAN-awareBridgeMode-ConfigureaVLAN-awareBridge
Is it a problem that the bridge interface config could be added after the 'post' config for swp1 and swp2?

It shouldn't be a problem, as `net add bridge bridge ports swp1` implies the creation of the bridge. See https://docs.cumulusnetworks.com/display/DOCS/VLAN-aware+Bridge+Mode#VLAN-awareBridgeMode-ConfigureaVLAN-awareBridge

Alternatively we could write out all the .pre lines, then all the .config lines, then all the .post lines.

+1 - its not entirely clear from the nclu docs, but "A single, multi-line string with jinja2 formatting. This string will be broken by lines, and each line will be run through net", which makes me think order matters. Maybe cumulus_switch_interface_config should be a list of dicts?

This is a general problem with Kayobe physical network configuration. With the code in main.yml, Cumulus will try to apply all changes in one transaction: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/636941/1/ansible/roles/cumulus-switch/tasks/main.yml

However, some operations require a specific state to be present. For example, an interface needs to be removed from a bridge before being added to a bond. This is why I added the "pre" commands, in which a manual commit can be included.

Yes! Cleaning up during postcommit turns out often to be easier than doing it during precommit. In this case, during precommit, the L3P's DB rows still exist, so querying to find out whether any other L3Ps still reference the resources requires first explicitly removing those references from the L3P that is being deleted. But during postcommit, this L3P's DB rows are already gone, and only references from other L3Ps remain.
We should also call super(AIMMappingDriver, self).delete_l2_policy_precommit(context) here I think?

There is no longer any inherited delete_l2_policy_precommit to call, as the method in CommonNeutronBase was also moved to postcommit (and is called below). The only other implementation is in ResourceMappingDriver, which is not a base class. 

Note that this driver is now only calling base class methods where needed - we've even defined no-op methods to make sure inherited methods are not unintentionally executed (see lines 665-687). Ideally, we'll eventually do some refactoring of the driver inheritance tree to make it clearer what functionality is being reused across drivers, but that seemed out of scope for this patch.

I didn't see any point in moving them. I think it's best to keep the AIM state transactional with the GBP resource state where possible. Only the create methods generally needed to move the AIM resource management to postcommit, and that is because the values might depend on resources implicitly-created during postcommit. 

Also, if there is a failure during create_*_postcommit, delete is called to cleanup afterwards, returning everything to the initial state. But we don't have anything similar to undo partial updates from update_*_postcommit methods that fail. Therefore, I think updating AIM resources during precommit is preferable.

https://opendev.org/x/group-based-policy/src/branch/master/gbpservice/neutron/services/grouppolicy/drivers/resource_mapping.py#L875-L876

Right. In general, it is only the REST API method implementations (other than gets) that have transaction guards.  Methods like _add_nat_pool_to_segment and _set_db_np_subnet modify the DB and are intended to be called within transactions, and therefore must avoid calling REST API methods. If they did need to call REST API methods, they would need to be called outside transactions, and would need to manage local transactions when accessing the DB.

My understanding is that transaction guards were added upstream in order to ensure that code wasn't merged that would result in ML2 mechanism driver postcommit methods and in-process callbacks for events such as BEFORE_* and AFTER_* being called inside a transaction, as those methods might make RPC or REST API calls on other processes.

These methods are intended to be called within transactions, and therefore they avoid calling REST API methods that have transaction guards.

inside _process_ext_segment_update_for_nat_pool() its calling 2 functions like this,
context._plugin._set_db_np_subnet(
                context._plugin_context, context.current, None)
            self._add_nat_pool_to_segment(context)

Will it violate the transaction guard principal then?

https://opendev.org/x/group-based-policy/src/branch/master/gbpservice/neutron/services/grouppolicy/drivers/resource_mapping.py#L912-L914
Should this if-elif block be also moved to inside the transaction at line#1499 below because _use_implicit_subnetpool() could also create an implicit subnetpool first?

I assume the reason you created a transaction below at line# 1499 is to make sure things are either done all at once or not at all. And since inside _use_implicit_subnetpool(), it will call _create_implicit_subnetpool() which is a also write operation. That's why I asked maybe we should move all the write operations into this newly created transaction.

We definitely cannot call _use_implicit_subnetpool from within a transaction, so I think it must be called here, before the transaction. The call to _add_subnetpools_to_l3_policy is moved from the elif clause to the transaction. I'm not sure I understand exactly what you are asking.

Since create_subnetpool is a Neutron REST API, it should not be called within a transaction, and therefore _use_implicit_subnetpool should not be called within a transaction. The next patch in this series replaces the disable_transaction_guard decorator on the ML2Plus plugin's create_subnetpool method with a transaction_guard decorator.

Also, even though we'd like things to be as atomic as possible, we are not always able to do everything necessary in a single transaction. Particularly in create methods, we depend on the plugin deleting a partially constructed resource after an exception occurs while it is being created.
Since these PT deletions were moved out of the transaction then I think the comment here doesn't apply any more?
Good point - will remove the comment.

docker/jitsi-meet/Dockerfile.message: If you wanted you could just tack it onto this earlier apt-get command by specifying debhelper/stretch-backports for the package name and save the extra apt-get invocation, but this will also work fine.

This worked for me locally:

        mkdir -p /usr/share/man/man1/ && \
        apt-get update && \
        apt-get dist-upgrade -y && \
        apt-get install -y apt-transport-https \
                apt-utils ca-certificates gnupg git build-essential fakeroot \
                devscripts openjdk-8-jre-headless openjdk-8-jdk-headless maven && \
        echo "deb http://ftp.debian.org/debian stretch-backports main" > /etc/apt/sources.list.d/backports.list && \
        apt-get update && \
        apt-get install -y -t stretch-backports debhelper && \
        rm /etc/apt/sources.list.d/backports.list && \
        apt-get update && \
        curl -sS https://deb.nodesource.com/gpgkey/nodesource.gpg.key | \
                apt-key add - && \

Yep, that's what I was suggesting.

Yup, this is meant to parallel the bdm/network approaches.

I have a doubt, if the 'accel:device_profile' in the instance's flavor, but the instance already lose the accelerator device (the device is offline), How do we do this scenario?

* If the active instance lost the accerator device, is it in a state of death? (It's in active status, but cannot do nothing)

    NOTE: IMO, if the hardware of an instance in the running state is lost, it will be suspended.

* If we hard reboot or soft reboot *this* instance, does it become ERROR?

Therefore, when we delete ARQ, do we need to determine whether the device accelerator used by this instance still exists? Does it exist to raise an exception?

Many of these questions are very broad in scope, and the answers may vary substantially across devices. Most of them seem to be outside the scope of Cyborg/OpenStack.

 > I have a doubt, if the 'accel:device_profile' in the instance's
 > flavor, but the instance already lose the accelerator device (the
 > device is offline), How do we do this scenario?

If the accelerator device is not responding to PCI transactions, it may trigger a fatal machine check error in the system, causing a host crash. This is outside of Cyborg/OpenStack, or even qemu/libvirt.

 > * If the active instance lost the accerator device, is it in a
 > state of death? (It's in active status, but cannot do nothing)

What does 'lost' mean? If the device responds to PCI transactions, but its computation is hanging/deadlocked, I suppose it is possible for the instance to be active while the accelerator is 'lost'. But one would expect that the application or the device driver has a timeout for unresponsive devices. These are general questions outside the scope of Cyborg.

 > NOTE: IMO, if the hardware of an instance in the running state is
 > lost, it will be suspended.

Have you actually seen such behavior? I have seen host crashes when the device fails PCI transactions, but haven't seen the VM getting suspended. Which entity will suspend the instance?

 > * If we hard reboot or soft reboot *this* instance, does it become
 > ERROR?

Depends on what happens when the instance disconnects from the device after a reboot. Some devices may do an automatic reset, perhaps a PCI FLR. That can result in or trigger device errors if the device was already in a bad state.

 > Therefore, when we delete ARQ, do we need to determine whether the
 > device accelerator used by this instance still exists? Does it
 > exist to raise an exception?

First, it is not Nova's job to check the device state. Secondly, though the Cyborg agent scans the compute host periodically for discovery, when a device is assigned to a VM, its PCI function will not show up in the host scan. So, Cyborg would not know about its health, unless programming failed or something. In short, my answer to these questions is No.

If this exception path is hit, that means one of the following happened:
A. Failed to invoke Cyborg's POST call to create ARQs in [1].

   only be because one of these:
   1. Failed to invoke Cyborg's PATCH call to bind ARQs in [1].
   2. Contacted Cyborg but binding failed within Cyborg for some reason. 
      Note that the binding is async, so device config/programming errors will not cause this.
      Today the binding failure should not happen, because Cyborg fails it for one of two validation errors:
      a. The patch list for binding is bad [2]. Nova shouldn't hit this.
      b. In the future, if Cyborg makes ARQ deletions async, the instance could be bound to
         another set of ARQs during rescheduling due to a possible race. See [3]. But that's not the case today.

For cases A and B, no cleanup is needed. For C, technically, we should cleanup the newly created ARQs. However:

 . Note that C-1 is the main concern today, as C-2 should not happen today as things stand. 
 . For the case C-1, there is no guarantee that the DELETE API call will succeed when the PATCH API call failed right before that.
 . Since the ARQs were not bound to an instance, delete_arqs_by_instance() [4] would not work. However, Cyborg has another form DELETE /accelerator_requests that deletes by ARQ UUIDs. 
 . Though newly created (unbound) ARQs are relatively inexpensive resources (they only consume an entry in a db table), it is probably not a good idea to leave them around. 
 . So, we should probably use the alternative API to delete ARQs by UUIDs. However, that call is not idempotent [5], so we have to take extra care not to call it twice.

It would be good to discuss this further.

No, use assertRaises(). As I said before, if you're expecting that an exception is raised, re-raised, transformed, or whatever, you should use assertRaises(). Otherwise if your code *stops* raising that exception, you will fail.

In this case, you clearly want to make sure that if some unexpected exception is raised, it gets transformed into a BuildAbortException. That's good, so you should make sure that raising TestingException results in a BuildAbortException. Your code here will fail if the exception becomes different, but it will not fail if the context manager *stops* raising an exception. That's the difference, and that's the important detail.

My original idea was to decrease the burden on small projects like stables, but you are right

Precisely speaking, dropping something from lower-constraints breaks the concept of lower-constraints job. lower-constraints.txt covers not only direct dependencies but also indirect dependencies.

Let's assume a project foo (networking-bgpvpn in this case) requires libfoo>=1.1 and libfoo requires libbar>=1.2.
In this case, lower-constraints.txt should contain libfoo==1.1 and libbar==1.2.

Otherwise, if libbar 1.3 is released, libbar 1.3 will be used in lower-constraints job. This is not what is expected.
In worst case, libbar 2.0 which is incompatible with 1.x, the lower-constraints job could break.

This is the reason we include indirect dependencies in lower-constraints.txt. The same is also applied to upper-constraints.txt.
Is 2.0.1 ok for pyScss2 or shall I add 2.0.0 to lower-constraints?
we succeeded to revive pyscss and a new version of horizon which uses a new pyscss 1.3.6 has been released, so we can switch back to pyScss (1.3.6).

Colleen, thank you very much for the detail. I now understand why "ignore" totally makes sense. The actual behavior depends on keystone.conf and these options passed via the API just control whether the corresponding security compliance options are honored or ignored. I believe I also now understand why you commented "(default)" is not correct in a past patch set.

> question to both Colleen and Vishakha: Colleen suggested
 > --no-ignore-change-password-upon-first-use. What is the difference
 > between --no-change-change-password-upon-first-use and
 > --change-password-upon-first-use? Generally speaking, double
 > inverse makes it difficult to understand the meaning. From OSC user
 > perspective, it is better to avoid using double inverse as much as
 > possible. Vishakha replaced all 'enable'/'disable' to
 > 'ignore'/'--no-ignore' based on Colleen's suggestion. Could you
 > check double inverse makes sense one by one?
 > 
 > Honestly I still cannot understand why 'ignore' is so important? Is
 > it because it matches keystone implementations?
 > 
 > For example, --no-ignore-lock-failure-attempts means
 > lockout_failure_attempts is applied to the user. When I see
 > --no-ignore-lockout-failure-attempts I thought it means it enables
 > lock-failure-attempts, but from keystone perseecitve and Colleen's
 > suggestion, it looks more than that and perhaps I am missing
 > something.

'ignore' is important here because these options aren't being applied to a user in a vacuum, they exist in order to opt users out of global settings that are set in keystone.conf. Consider this example:

* [security_compliance]/change_password_upon_first_use=true in keystone.conf

==> this means that ALL users in keystone MUST change their password before they are able to get a token

* set {"options": {"ignore_change_password_upon_first_use": true}} for user nova

==> this means that the nova service user is not required to change its password on first use. This is desirable if we want to apply a global security compliance setting for human users but need to make exceptions for automated or service users

* set {"options": {"ignore_change_password_upon_first_use": true}} for user bob

==> oops! bob is a human user, this is a mistake: we actually do want bob to be forced to change his password before logging in

* set {"options": {"ignore_change_password_upon_first_use": false}} for user bob

==> this reverses the option, it is the equivalent of removing the option, but the API doesn't allow removing the option because PATCH does a merge of the JSON object



Here's another example:

* There are no [security_compliance] settings set in keystone.conf. All users are free not to change their password and will not be locked out if they fail to authenticate.

* set {"options": {"ignore_change_password_upon_first_use": true}} for user bob

==> this has no effect, because change_password_upon_first_use is not set in keystone.conf.

* set {"options": {"ignore_change_password_uopn_first_use": false}} for user bob

==> this has no effect, because change_password_upon_first_use is not set in keystone.conf.



This is why 'ignore' is important, because we are *ignoring* a setting that exists on the backend, and it has no direct effect on the user if keystone isn't configured with these options on the backend.

This isn't the default, if this option is unset AND the related security_compliance option is set in keystone.conf, then the number of auth attempts is NOT ignored. I think neither the positive or negative cases should be considered 'default', in either case it is setting an option when it would otherwise be empty.
suggest instead "Opt into ignoring the number of times a user has authenticated and locking out the user as a result"

This is not what this does, rather it turns off the above ignoring of the security_compliance setting. Setting this on its own does not cause the user to be locked out after failed auth attempts. See https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/configuration.html#security-compliance for more information on what these settings are for.

Suggest instead "Opt out of ignoring the number of times a user has authenticated and locking out the user as a result."

Same comments for other security_compliance options below.
Again this is not the default, if unset users will not have MFA enabled. See https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/multi-factor-authentication.html#enabling-mfa
I think that would be fine, it's consistent with other flags for other commands and preserves the correct meaning.

I think this should be first. It looks tricky to start with an example.

So, this is why the test at the end of this series works, but doesn't actually put anything into the XML right? Because the type is TEST_PCI?

I think that we should at *least* LOG.warning() here for each accelerator we're ignoring because the type is unsupported. I would tend to argue that we should *fail* in that case so that people don't spin up instances with expensive accelerators (which billing will be charging for) and that we're silently ignoring.

> So, this is why the test at the end of this series works, but
 > doesn't actually put anything into the XML right? Because the type
 > is TEST_PCI?

Yes.

 > I think that we should at *least* LOG.warning() here for each
 > accelerator we're ignoring because the type is unsupported. I would
 > tend to argue that we should *fail* in that case so that people
 > don't spin up instances with expensive accelerators (which billing
 > will be charging for) and that we're silently ignoring.

All the devices that Cyborg supports now and in the near future are going to be with PCI passthrough. This case is going to be hit for the fake driver only. Warnings here will be distracting IMHO, but a LOG.info wouldn't hurt.

Further more, Cyborg documentation states which drivers/devices are supported. If we add a device with a different attach handle type, it will be considered unsupported till both Cyborg and Nova changes are done to enable it. In fact, PCI devices are listed as unsupported today since this patch series has not merged.

> My point is exactly for the case where everyone assumes PCI until
 > they don't. 

Just curious: what non-PCI device are you concerned about? If you are referring to PCI passthrough vs mediated devices, yes, that will require changes, but Cyborg will need changes too.

My concern is with putting checks/warnings now in anticipation of a future which may be a long while away. IMHO, it would be better to make the changes as we need them.

That said, please look at my next update, which should address some of your concerns at least.

 > > Further more, Cyborg documentation states which drivers/devices
 > are
 > > supported. If we add a device with a different attach handle
 > type,
 > > it will be considered unsupported till both Cyborg and Nova
 > changes
 > > are done to enable it. In fact, PCI devices are listed as
 > > unsupported today since this patch series has not merged.
 > 
 > This argument holds no weight for me at all. Silently ignoring
 > things is always bad.

Please see my rework of this logic in the next patch.

> Just curious: what non-PCI device are you concerned about? If you
 > are referring to PCI passthrough vs mediated devices, yes, that
 > will require changes, but Cyborg will need changes too.

I'm worried about things we don't support now, but will in the future. I want this code to be defensive and not just ignore things it doesn't know about. In some future someone will try to make changes to nova or cyborg in isolation, or run a newer cyborg with an older nova, etc. This code shouldn't just ignore things it is instructed to handle, but doesn't know about.

> All the devices that Cyborg supports now and in the near future are
 > going to be with PCI passthrough. This case is going to be hit for
 > the fake driver only. Warnings here will be distracting IMHO, but a
 > LOG.info wouldn't hurt.

My point is exactly for the case where everyone assumes PCI until they don't. I really feel like we should fail here, were it not for the TEST_PCI example. I think logging a warning in the TEST_PCI case is fine, and is the *minimum* we should do to highlight the mismatch on a real system.

 > Further more, Cyborg documentation states which drivers/devices are
 > supported. If we add a device with a different attach handle type,
 > it will be considered unsupported till both Cyborg and Nova changes
 > are done to enable it. In fact, PCI devices are listed as
 > unsupported today since this patch series has not merged.

This argument holds no weight for me at all. Silently ignoring things is always bad.

Surely this won't be the case forever, right? Can we not just assert that they are all the same? Combined with the above, we can probably build a list of things we're not going to attach (so we can warn/fail) and then just check that that list is empty.
Then there is zero problem with making the assertion that they're all PCI right?
Please see above. All the devices we plan to support, for the foreseeable future, are PCI passthrough. If we get something else, it is going to require multiple changes and appropriate documentation.
I made this change in the next patchset.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Please be more precise in describing what's going on here to help out people looking at the git history later.  I suggest something like

RBD: workaround for segfault during volume clone

for the title.  It doesn't seem like the rest of the commit message is describing what's going on in the patch, though, because if I'm counting correctly, your patch adds 1 more close() than we had previously.

Maybe:
This patch fixes a bug in volume cloning where the source volume was being prematurely closed.  If the destination volume required flattening, and a exception occurred during flattening, the code would attempt to perform cleanup operations on an already closed volume.  This resulted
in a segmentation fault which causes cinder to restart.

cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/test_rb.message: I think you need to add a reference to the LP bug here saying why this *must* be 1
Update coming shortly, thanks for mentioning this.
If the problem is that we're calling close() too many times, we should probably check to make sure that the 2x here are on different volumes.

No, we calling close twice, once for the source volume (for clone()) and one for the destination volume - which must be opened in order to call flatten() - this is where the second close() is coming from.

cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py.message: I think you need a comment explaining why it makes sense to do this here rather than in the 'finally' ... otherwise someone is going to eventually refactor this and move the close() back to a 'finally' clause as a "safer" way to do this.

It makes sense here because the source volume is closed further down for the non-exception case.  We only want to close here before the raise because we’re about to return to the caller (and opened volumes cannot be left in that state, the must be closed).
This is already done at line 761 in "finally", why duplicate it here?
I’m working on an update that removed the finally, it should look better there.
If an error occurs on src_volume.remove_snap() or so above, this won't happen -- I think we need the "finally" block.

If either of these raises an exception, we'll never close the src_volume.  So I think we need a try around these 2 lines, an except that's just a pass, and a finally that closes src_volume (that may be why there was a finally in the original code, it was just at the wrong level).  Then you just continue the current except block with line 702, remove line 709, and raise at line 110.  (So you're only going to close src_volume if you are going to raise an exception to exit the function, but you'll definitely close it.)

cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/test_da.message: Is there a reason this is going back in time? :)
Since we only support py3 now, there shouldn't be any need to import __future__.

This is only need for py2.5 and older, which none of our stable branches support.

Backports are allowed to make adjustments for when there are changes that require it. We have discussed this and that is expected to happen, otherwise we can't move forward.

Backports will not happen with this driver since the one in-tree does not work.

I thought we discussed this and agreed on it, isn't it?!?

Both Walter above and Brian in the offline email thread agreed that it's too onerous for driver maintainers like us to have different versions of the driver for python 3 vs python 2.

From Brian Rosmaita's email:
> 1. You can keep py2 compat code; we are allowing it in drivers
This is being proposed for the master branch, which is for ussuri. Py2 has been dropped. Remove this.

The problem with that statement is the policy we have in place for fixing bugs, must be against master and then cherry picked into the previous release.  By forcing driver maintainers to remove all backwards compatible code, this makes it even more difficult for driver maintainers to maintain their code.   

The majority of us users don't use the latest version of openstack and often stick with older versions due to the expense and risk of upgrading.   

We already agreed to allow driver maintainers to leave six usage in their drivers, why not this when it doesn't harm the codebase.   I think when we end of life py2 supported release, then we can talk about removing all backwards compatible code.  This is the first release that's py3 only.

Open stack might have transitioned to python 3, but the goal here is to make this driver be backward compatible to other versions of Openstack - we unfortunately have customers that are still on Newton. One of our design goals was to be able to support both python2 and python3 and we intend to keep it that way for as long as possible.

This applies to some other places too.
Another side effect of py3-only is that we no longer want to use the third party mock library. "from unittest import mock" can be used instead.

Either that or list 1.0 ... 2.4.0 from the stable/train version, and just add 2019.12.10.0 with the description "accumulated changes since 2.4.0, see <url> for details".  Actually, maybe this is my preference, it reflects reality more closely.

Most drivers have this copied & pasted into doc/source/drivers.rst (where Datera isn't currently represented, btw).  But I think it would be good to have the info here in case we write a sphinx directive to extract the version history directly from the python class at some point.  I think most reviewers consider the version history in the python class to be the source of truth.

I don't think any of the current drivers have version history in their individual driver doc page, like your current doc/source/configuration/block-storage/drivers/datera-volume-driver.rst

Anyway, I think (a) a version history is useful here, (b) it should reflect reality (more or less), and (c) you should whatever solution makes it the case that your in-tree driver does not diverge from your out-of-tree driver for this version.

sushycli system bios set attributes='{'BootMode':'Bios', 'EmbeddedSata':'Raid'...}'

Pretty sure I said this before, but I do not agree with the assertion that these should be run in alphabetical order. One filter may alter the request spec depending on the things done by a previous filter, and/or there may be dependencies at some point. Sorting these could totally introduce a behavioral change, especially later if someone adds something in one release that needs to go in the middle. The names of these are not visible to the operator, so the alphabetical nature isn't discoverable.

IMHO, we should append to the end of this list when adding one, unless there's a reason one filter needs to run before another (which is possible and legit), in which case it goes where it needs to go.

I *definitely* don't want you sorting this list in this patch as it's already doing too much.

The error was that previously safe_decode was used (and even the comment message, that suggests, that param would be str seems wrong) But using safe_encode looks like a good idea here.

Then we make sure that it's not empty string (as in it is specified and specifically set to '') and we do verification. Well, the critical part is the for loop at L245.  That is the main difference between this and allocate(). This doesn't seem to maintain the current behavior of randomizing inside a wide window (30) by default. It seems to effectively treat all single IP allocations as prefer_next, which doesn't provide the collision avoidance we want by default.
I'm now setting 30 as the floor size for the randomization window, or the size of av_set, whichever is smaller.

I understand your concern.  Do you have any suggestions on how to mitigate the potential negative impact, while still streamlining bulk port operations so that creating 1000 ports does not take more than an hour?

Please check bug:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1777968

It will make the situation even worse.

Such port creation (one by one) is originally started from nova, when user parallelly create 1000 VM of one single subnet, nova will create the port one by one.

For the bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1777968 I filed here, is an extreme scenario testing to simulate nova create port.

So window 1 is not so much good for such scenario, the DBDeadlockError and IP address collision will raise again. And the VM will get failed to create.

So, here you should mark the call whether is bulk allocation. If not, give it a large window size to provent the collision.

Ryan, while there is a lot of sense what you suggest, there is one constraint which prevent us from opening window to entire av_set. While in case of IPv4 it is feasible to do that, than on huge set of IPv6 it may take a huge amount of time to make a list out of IPSet generator, or even crash. I've already explained that in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/611341/5/neutron/ipam/drivers/neutrondb_ipam/driver.py@173. That's why we need large enough, but at least  some large window.

I keep re-reading this and I keep thinking this is problematic in that it doesn't really select random IP's for single IP allocations. Nor does it really randomize the selection of bulk addresses, only the order in which they are returned in the list.

This code was initially written with single IP allocations in mind. The algorithm's use of a window and ip_index are suited for picking out a psuedo-random IP address  to avoid collisions. The way this is written, your window is going to be the same size as num_addresses unless you don't have enough addresses to allocate (min(av_set, num_addresses)). If you have more available (av_set.size) in the subnet than num_addresses, window will be num_addresses. This will cause ip_index to always be equal to num_addresses, and your list of candidate IP's doesn't leave any room for randomizing. The candidate list will be the length of num_addresses, which means we will always grab the first N addresses. No randomization, which means collisions.

Someone else should check my reading of this code, but I don't think this is actually avoiding collisions for bulk allocations. It also doesn't seem to randomize selection of single IP addresses correctly, meaning there's a regression here and we're back to fighting with collisions on basic allocations.

Ryan has right. Here is my analysis:

Suppose we have 2 clients, who requests 10 VMs at the same time. What we do have here is initially window size set to 10 for both of them (L181). Let's assume, that av_ips.size is equal to 100.

Next (L182) there is an ip_index calculated out of requested addresses (10) and window (10), which gives… 10 (and BTW, this line is useless and can be safely removed).

(L183) candidate_ips are sliced from the num_address and there will be created a list of first… 10 IPs from available set. For BOTH of the clients.

Let's stop for a second - sets are unordered by their nature, but we cannot rely of their randomness either, so it's a big chance, that both clients got similar set of available ips. Second, IPSet object is not a set. It's a generator. I don't analyze the code, but it's a fat chance that it might be ordered in certain way.

And now sit back, take your popcorn and watch like two workers trying to allocate IPs from the same (or almost the same) set of list which length is… 10 :D

So in L182 we return a random pick, which I think greatly assists preventing collisions.  

Also this logic uses as a window up to the entire selectable set of addresses in the pool.  So I think we actually do as much as possible to avoid deadlocks or collisions.  I also expect that most tenants will either use this kind of mulk allocation, or they will use standard behavior, but that there will be little mixing of behaviors in practice.

Here is what I would suggest, but first a little background:

The reason we put a window in place for single allocations was to keep allocations from being pulled from all over the subnet. The thinking was that users tend to prefer contiguous allocations, so allocating within a window rather than the entire subnet helps keep the next address allocated "close" to the "front" of the subnet. In retrospect, I don't think people really care. It's purely cosmetic, and really is no help in avoiding collisions. In fact, we have had to come back expand the window from 10 to 30 because we found collisions were still happening under load.

For bulk allocations, I would throw the notion of a selection window out (the window...... :) ). I'm in favor of opening the entire subnet (within the bounds of allocation pools) as the availability set (av_set). Then, when you perform a bulk allocation you can simply sample random indices from the availability set to generate allocated_ip_pool. It's very naive, but to me it feels like a good starting point from which we can begin to optimize. I don't believe we will get this perfectly optimized with this patch on the first try.
I rewrote this section taking advantage of the facilities in the random module, which I think will give a more robust implementation of the randomness we are trying to achieve here.

I wasn't considering IPv6, so my comments were only half-baked :). You also helped jog my memory, IPv6 was a consideration. You're absolutely right, we can't open the entire subnet.

We could adjust this so that window bounds are placed randomly around the subnet, and addresses are sampled from the window. This would have the effect of randomizing where different transactions attempt to allocate from. With larger subnets, the effect could be quite noticeable. As written, the size of the subnet doesn't really matter. The bounds of the selection window cause contention for the first N available addresses in the subnet. Even though it shifts as addresses are allocated, the window generally presents most of the same addresses in the av_set each time this runs. If the av_set presented to each transaction is shuffled, that would help cut down on contention.

We could also play with the size of the window, although that feels a little advanced and it may not buy us anything in practice.
That condition can be safely removed. It's already checked in L171. Window cannot be smaller than num_addresses, hence the check, while window itself cannot be larger than… requested num_address.
Done
List is all we need here. Just to store already visited random index.
Done

And yeah. So there is an iteration over requested num_addresses, and there is a candidate_ips list, which is equal to num_addresses, and still, what is done here is picking random address from that range, until done. Or fail in scenario I've described in line 181.

What is the purpose of the shuffle step? Once we've sampled we've already narrowed down the set of IP addresses to allocate. Bulk addresses selected by bulk allocation effectively follow set semantics. I think we can do without shuffling the sample set, since we should think of it as a set (even though we return a list). Perhaps working with a set might make this more clear?

I was mostly trying to figure out how to most efficiently respond to your suggestion on the previous patchset, "If the av_set presented to each transaction is shuffled, that would help cut down on contention."

I'll remove it given that the sampling is sufficient for our needs.

I see, I guess I wasn't very clear so my apologies. I was thinking that we could somehow sample from av_set to generate a selection window, then sample again from that sampled window. That way each transaction selects from a different set of addresses.

However what I'm describing could be overkill. I like what you've done at L183 and we should see what kind of mileage we get out of doing it this way, it's very simple and could be quite effective.

For larger subnets (of the IPv6 variety) list(av_set) seems to be the root of the unit test failures. Something like this seemed to reliably get around it:

stop = min(av_set.size, num_addresses * 2)
allocated_ip_pool = random.sample(list(itertools.islice(av_set, stop)), num_addresses)

This could be greatly refined, but the general idea is to generate a window of addresses to allocate from. Just some food for thought.

or even:

   window = min(av_set.size, num_addresses * some_arbitrary_multiplier)
   if window > some_arbitrary_max_len:
       window = some_arbitrary_max_len

Multiplier could be something like 10, or even 100 - having a slice of 10000 IPs shouldn't have significant impact on performance.

OTOH, if we would have single IP requested (num_addresses=1), and large amount of requests, in window like 2 or 10 or maybe even 100, than we end up in situation where workers again would fight for the IPs. Why not doing it like this:


    MAX_WIN = 1000
    MULTIPLIER = 100
    MAX_WIN_MULTI = MAX_WIN * MULTIPLIER
    ...
    window = min(av_set.size, MAX_WIN)

    # if there is more than one address, make the window bigger, so that
    # are chances to fulfill demanded amount of IPs
    if num_addresses > 1:
        window = min(av_set.size, num_addresses * MULTIPLIER)
        if window > MAX_WIN_MULTI:
            window = MAX_WIN_MULTI

    if window < num_addresses:
        continue

    av_ips = list(itertootls.islice(0, window))

The only issue here is allocation of amount of addresses which are equal, or near the window size. In this case it is almost guaranteed that allocation will fail. We have to have *some* area to randomly pick address from. The higher the window, higher are chances to avoid collisions.

I can imagine, in some huge cloud, that someone wanted to spin up 2000 VMs (why not?) in this case, even 1000 window would be too small.

What I'm really thinking of right now is to divide such request into bunch of smaller ones (like allocating 100 IPs 20 times) so that probability of the succeed is much higher, than enlarging the window. It's even better from performance perspective, because transaction would be done only for those 100 IPs, and retry mechanism in case of failure could be implemented in upper level.

So if you're thinking about batching the requests in the context of concurrent requests, then I guess the trick is to allocate a batch and then recalculate av_set to account for the fact that a concurrent request has also allocated a batch for itself in the background.  You'd want the batch to be relatively large so that you had to do a minimum number of those recalculations of av_set, but also small enough that you would have a good chance of passing it through without contention elsewhere.  Given that the batch will be a set selected from a random sampling of requests from the block - and so already the risk of contention is somewhat mitigated - do you think it's reasonable to size each block as a set fraction of the total number of requested addresses, if the total number of requested addresses is larger than some arbitrary limit?

Do we even want to mix IPv6 with IPv4 pools? It's possible to create one, big set of available addresses, like:

    …

    for ip_pool in self.subnet_manager.list_pools(context):
        ip_set = netaddr.IPSet()
        ip_set.add(netaddr.IPRange(ip_pool.first,
                                   ip_pool.last_ip))
        av_set.add(ip_set.difference(ip_allocations))
