        …

although I don't have strong opinions regarding this. But, if ip_allocations is a set of mixed already allocated IPs from all pools (regardless it's IPv4 or IPv6), than it might work.
So yeah. Let's drop the idea.

We can't mix address families for allocation. Allocation is done in the context of a given subnet, not the network. The allocation pools we're talking about here are the allocation_pools for the subnet being operated on. Those allocation pools simply reserve blocks of addresses that IPAM won't allocate from.
If there would be any IP, which is included in the list, already allocated by concurrent request, all of that bulk allocation will fail :(

In that case, also some kind of claim for the IP resources should be implemented, because it can happen, that 10 users wil ask for 100 IPs, but we do have available like 500, so every user wil stuck in error state, because of inability to reserve IPs.

Yes, but what is the alternative? Run each individual allocation in its own transaction? That doesn't scale. I suppose there are more elaborate schemes we can look at that commit in chunks, but rolling back the entire allocation becomes a mess. In the end, I think it's best if bulk allocations are handled as a single transaction. This isn't perfect, but the question of the size of the bulk allocation requests we get is an important factor in how many deadlock retries this generates.

I'm a believer in starting simple. If we put a hard-coded bound on the size of bulk allocations *some* users may have to run multiple bulk allocations when they deploy, but I don't see that to be as much of a problem as attempting to engineer a more complex allocation algorithm that needs to be maintained. It's also better than not doing anything and just letting user requests fail.

I'm not sure what kind of partitioning could be applied equally in all of the possible scenarios here:

- Requesting 1 IP, 2 available
- Requesting 1000 IPs, 1001 available
- Requesting 10 IPs, 1,000,000,000 available
- etc.

At the neutron-server level, if 10 users ask for 100 IPs out of a pool of 500, I think it is acceptable for them all to get an error back - because then they will need to retry, and hopefully that retry will not occur simultaneously.  If we add a reservation system, do we not just add an abstraction layer that they would then experience contention with?  I'm not sure the cost-benefit ratio is positive for handling these particular kinds of edge scenarios, although I am of an open mind to be persuaded otherwise.  I additionally am concerned that such a system will slow down the overall transaction, since the goal of the BP is speed.

Here's a crazy idea: what if we were to take the subnet (or av_set) and partition it so that somehow we hash each transaction to a segment of the availability set? This way each transaction only sees a subset of the available addresses, samples from that segment, and contention only occurs when 2 transactions happen to hash to the same segment of the subnet?

I think we need to start thinking outside of the box, you're raising some really good points that have me questioning everything we've done with IPAM here :)

I agree with your thoughts about a reservation system. It just pushes the problem around, it doesn't go away. Perhaps we're over-thinking this and we should just run with this and see where it gets us.

Ryan, I've also thought about some kind of window within window, just to have it shifted from other requests. BUT. I could see three potential problems with such approach:

1. There is no guarantee, that such subset of the window will be different enough between the requests (i.e. we could easly have overlapping subsets for two or more concurrent requests. That could happen if we provide some algorithm for calculation of the starting point for the subset within window.
2. If we make sure, to have non-overlapping subsets, there is a possibility, that it might produce very long window to fit such requests
3. still, if there are requests form single address out there, they would have precedence over bulk one, simply because of the creation of smaller set of addresses to pick one from is faster (see the timings around line 38)

Overall, I think, that decision about the parameters for bulk process shouldn't be done in driver, but in higher layer, so it will have the picture on whole process, and could do some retries for failed allocations (in case of using a set of smaller requested IPs amount)

FWIW, I would never block a schema change because the initial spec didn't include it. The spec is a place to work out the overall architecture of the library, not a place to document every single detail of the implementation. If there are fields that would be useful but aren't included in this list we can add them without worrying about this.

That said, there _should_ be up to date documentation of the schema in the oslo.metrics docs.

nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
So this was intended to collapse 'compute_nodes' table records that have the same 'host' but different "node" into single records (in ironic, for example: ComputeNode(host='host1', node='node1'), ComputeNode(host='host1', node='node2') represent two ironic nodes that have the same nova-compute service on host1)

But it wasn't doing that for anything other than postgres and was/is instead just taking distinct rows (which the above example would _not_ be collapsed and thus not do what was intended).

And it apparently doesn't matter because the left table in the join is the 'services' table which has unique constraints on 'host', 'binary'/'topic', and 'deleted':

https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/commit/69ce0f01b60dfe0f020ac57eb82a42e5935064c4/nova/db/sqlalchemy/models.py#L81-L84

and we'll only take rows from the 'services' table that match 'compute_nodes' where hypervisor type matches.

All of this is to ask, should we keep distinct here at all? Am I missing a desired thing that it's doing?

from my pov distinct() is usually not that useful with full object queries, not to mention it's a poor performer, because it's having to DISTINCT every column you're getting back.  The ORM already "uniques" all the objects coming back on primary key identity so this can't actually change the result.  So it's likely you might want to take this out altogether.

Okay, disregard this one. I dug a bit more and talked to gibi & Dan. For future me:

ResourceRequest.__init__ is fine for simple culling of flavor/image-meta. But there are other things that need request groups that come from "outside". For example, bandwidth request groups come from the port associated with the boot request. Those kinds of things we process in _provision_instances while building the RequestSpec, and stuff them into RequestSpec.requested_resources. Then finally select_destinations calls resources_from_request_spec which does the ResourceRequest.__init__ and then *adds* the RequestSpec.resource_requests [1].

Accelerator request groups come from the device profile associated with the boot request. Today that association happens to be via flavor extra specs, so technically we could do the processing from here (ResourceRequest.__init__) as suggested in my previous comment. BUT the eventual goal is to make it possible to specify device profiles as parameters to the boot request (more like ports), so it will need to be done from _provision_instances and populated into RequestSpec.requested_resources.

[1] That last part, the separation of ResourceRequest.__init__ and appending RequestSpec.resource_requests, didn't make sense to me, so I proposed https://review.opendev.org/696354
